Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of seniors who died from the COVID vaccine by suggesting that it is happening "around the world" and implying a widespread issue.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that seniors who died after receiving the COVID vaccine were improperly listed as "natural causes."
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the deaths of seniors who received the COVID vaccine were directly caused by the vaccine without providing any substantial evidence to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no evidence linking the deaths of seniors, such as Hank Aaron, in Gibraltar, and Norway to the COVID vaccine.
Understate: The claim understates the role of COVID-19 in the deaths of seniors by suggesting that their cause of death was listed as "natural causes" without acknowledging the potential impact of the virus.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for the deaths of seniors, such as underlying health conditions or other factors unrelated to the COVID vaccine.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on a source, Dr. Joseph Mercola, who has faced criticism from federal agencies and the medical community for his anti-vaccine efforts.
